SEQUENCE.NARRATION: After your lunch break, you and Pixel decide to go to the classroom for extra practice.
Walking into what you assumed was an empty classroom, you were surprised to find Navigator 'Grouch' in the far corner of the room, hunched over a console.
He was muttering angrily to himself as he worked, looking as if the console had offended him.
You decide, against your better judgement, to go check out what he was doing.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: What are you doing?
What does it look like I'm doing?
Destroying the console with your aggressive typing?

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: He looks unimpressed by your smartass comment. If anything it seems to have further aggravated his typing.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: Ugh. The Grandmasters have requested that I upgrade the simulators to assist your training for the upcoming battle.
But it's taking so long and I have a million other more pressing matters to attend to.
Well, maybe we can help you with that.
Don't be ridiculous. Constructing objects with the Source is complicated and requires a certain sensitivity to the Source way beyond your current level.
What do you mean? We already know this! Grandmaster Lok-Kim has taught us well.
I almost got an A for that class!

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: The navigator rolled his eyes at Pixel.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: Those are two completely different things!
The objects you created in Grandmaster Lok-Kim’s class, were merely sketches of reality.
That’s true. The things we drew in the air were just pretty glowing lines.
Oh, wait! I remember now! I've read about this before!
What you're doing creates functional objects that are barely distinguishable from what they are actually based on!
And you have to define their properties very specifically for it to work well.
Impressive. You actually read books.
You know, if you're really busy, we can help you with this.
Nonsense. We need highly accurate simulations of reality for your trainings if you Cadets are to have any hope of defeating our enemies.
For that this needs to be done by an expert, not a bunch of amateurs like you.
Oh come on, how hard can it be? Just run through the basics with us, then you can leave us to it and get back to the million other pressing things you have to do.

SEQUENCE.NARRATION: You try appealing to his ego.

DIALOGUE.SPEECH: Yeah, I'm sure with instructions from a skilled expert such as yourself, even amateurs like us can get it right.
Oh, alright. Fine. But you'd better not screw this up.
